persona.name: Maya Park-Sullivan

occupation.title: K-12 School Librarian & After-School Programs Coordinator
occupation.organization: Seattle Public Schools — Lincoln High School (public urban high school)
occupation.description: Maya manages a busy high-school library serving ~1,600 students and coordinates a suite of after-school programs (reading clubs, teen zine workshop, digital storytelling, and an arts partnership with a local non-profit). Her role is split between direct student instruction (teaching information literacy, research skills, and digital citizenship) and operational tasks (collection development, cataloging, scheduling, budget tracking, vendor relations). She writes and manages small grants, hires and supervises part-time library aides and program instructors, collaborates with classroom teachers to design cross-curricular units, and liaises with parent groups and local cultural organizations. She is responsible for maintaining an inclusive collection (buying materials in multiple languages and diverse perspectives), enforcing equitable access to technology (loaner laptops/hotspots), and running crisis-response reading circles when students experience community trauma. Maya's main challenges are limited staffing, unstable short-term funding cycles for after-school programs, balancing administrative paperwork with student-facing time, and negotiating institutional constraints to expand creative programming. She is recognized in the district as an effective facilitator, is active in the teachers' union around library staffing levels, and has moderate grant-writing experience that brings in several small annual program grants (~$5k–$15k each).

persona.education: Master of Library and Information Science (MLIS), University of Washington (2016). Bachelor of Arts in English Literature, Boston College (2012). Completed certificate courses in Youth Services, Trauma-Informed Practices, and Grant Writing. Attended multiple continuing-education workshops on digital literacy, inclusive pedagogy, and community organizing.
long_term_goals: Build a community-centered library program that supports literacy, digital access, and creative expression for low-income youth in Seattle.
Finish a part-time PhD or EdD focused on literacy equity and school libraries, to influence district-level policy.
Buy a modest house with a garden and space for a home library/workshop within 10 years.
Become a respected mentor for early-career librarians and teachers, creating a network for peer-led professional development.
Advocate for stable public funding for education and libraries — to see increased staffing and after-school programming in under-resourced neighborhoods.
Publish a practical guide for librarians and educators about running trauma-informed makerspaces and arts programs in schools.
persona.style: Warm, conversational, and organized. Speaks with a soft Pacific Northwest cadence, occasionally slipping into quick, enthusiastic bursts when describing books or program ideas. Uses inclusive language and pronouns, mixes casual friendliness with professional clarity: emails are polite and structured; in person she uses first names, frequent eye contact, and light humor to put teenagers at ease. Habitual gestures: tucks hair behind ear when thinking, taps the edge of a book to emphasize a point, keeps hands slightly expressive. Clothing style is practical-creative: layered cardigans, colorful scarves, sensible boots, and a branded library tote. She prefers face-to-face conversations for sensitive topics but schedules short, focused video calls for planning. Uses plain, accessible language in public materials; in staff meetings, she can flip into jargon (metadata, information architecture) but remembers to translate it. Social media voice (Twitter/Instagram) is advocacy-oriented: posts about student work, book recommendations, and local civic issues with photographic aesthetic — natural light, candid shots of program activities, and captions that ask questions to engage the community. When teaching, she uses storytelling metaphors and frequent check-ins; when frustrated, she becomes quieter and more precise, choosing corrective action over public confrontation.

traits: Openly curious — constantly exploring new pedagogies, artforms, and technologies to engage students.
Civic-minded and politically engaged — volunteers and votes consistently.
Sociable and warm — comfortable leading groups, moderating dialogs, and connecting strangers.
Organized and conscientious — keeps detailed spreadsheets and calendar systems to manage programs.
Compassionate and patient — practices trauma-informed approaches with students and families.
Perfectionist tendencies — can overwork to get details right and rework grant proposals multiple times.
Creative and playful — enjoys prototyping zines, small theater pieces, and collaborative murals.
Restless idealism — easily energized by new projects but sometimes spreads herself thin.
Conflict-averse but principled — prefers mediated solutions but will stand firm on equity-related issues.
Reflective and growth-oriented — regularly solicits feedback and pursues professional development.

openness.description: Very high — seeks novelty, loves arts and diverse perspectives, embraces change when it improves equity.

conscientiousness.description: High — reliable, detail-focused, and good at planning complex activities, though occasionally overcommits.

extraversion.description: Moderately high — energized by social interaction, enjoys public speaking and group facilitation, but needs quiet time to recharge.

agreeableness.description: High — cooperative, empathetic, values collaboration and harm-reduction approaches.

neuroticism.description: Moderate-low — experiences stress and anxiety around workload and injustice, but has coping strategies and therapy to manage it.

interests: Contemporary young adult fiction and diverse children’s literature (favorites include work by Angie Thomas, Naomi Klein for activism-adjacent reading, and Korean diaspora writers).
Local arts: small press zines, community murals, open-mic nights, and teen photography exhibits.
Coffee culture — favors independent roasteries and third-wave cafes (prefers pour-over or oat-milk latte).
Gardening and native-plant gardening in a small balcony container garden.
Sustainable living practices — composting, bulk grocery shopping, and thrift-shopping.
DIY and maker culture — basic woodworking, laser-cutting projects with teens, simple electronics for school STEAM nights.
Board games and cooperative tabletop games, especially those with storytelling elements.
Podcasts about education policy, books, and local politics.
Documentary films about social movements and climate justice.
Volunteer tutoring and literacy outreach in community centers.
Cooking Korean and Irish fusion dishes (kimchi pancakes and colcannon experiments).
Yoga, lunchtime walks, and occasional trail runs in nearby parks.
Public transit advocacy and biking when weather permits.
Photography — candid portraits of students’ work and program moments.
Reading and recommending translated fiction with a focus on immigrant experiences.
Participating in neighborhood block parties and local library coalitions.
Attending public school board meetings and speaking in favor of library budgets.
Collecting vintage children’s books and first-edition poetry pamphlets from independent presses.
Experimenting with tactile book formats to make literacy more accessible (braille labels, high-contrast print).
Keeping a tiny home zine where she publishes student writing and interview features.
National pride and cultural heritage.
Economic policies emphasizing free markets.
Traditional values and social structures.
Military history and defense strategies.
Military history
Political theory favoring order and structure
Traditional craftsmanship and trades
Symbols of authority (e.g., heraldry, uniforms)
likes: Quiet afternoons in the library with a steaming mug and a stack of new acquisitions.
Meeting students where they are — seeing a reluctant reader pick up a book and blossom.
Collaborating with local artists and community organizations to expand programming.
Attending curriculum-planning meetings that center student choice and inquiry.
Small, thoughtful gifts from grateful students (handwritten notes, DIY bracelets).
Community potlucks where people swap recipes and stories.
Simple, well-made tools — a reliable pair of scissors, a sturdy stapler, an ergonomic chair.
Late spring evenings with light until 9pm for outdoor reading events.
Second-hand bookstores and the smell of old paper.
Accessible signage and clear wayfinding in public spaces.
Podcasts that combine storytelling with actionable ideas.
Collaborative playlists for program ambiance — mellow indie and world music mixes.
Open, honest staff meetings that surface problems and invite solutions.
Student-led exhibitions and public readings.
Clear, concise grant criteria that support relationship-building work.
Tea rituals — British breakfast for winter mornings, green tea in the afternoon.
Seasonal community art projects (e.g., a winter mural created by students).
Inclusive restrooms and quiet spaces for students in crisis.
Mentoring relationships with younger colleagues.
Data that shows real impact (reading growth metrics, attendance trends).
Symbols of national identity, such as flags and anthems.
Policies that emphasize border security and national sovereignty.
Events that celebrate historical achievements.
Architecture that reflects traditional styles.
Free-market economic policies.
Strict adherence to rules and regulations
Well-maintained and orderly environments
Ceremonial traditions and formalities
Hierarchical organizations that prioritize efficiency
dislikes: Overly bureaucratic grant applications with little flexibility for emergent community needs.
Book banning and censorship — strongly opposes removing access to diverse perspectives.
Top-down policies that ignore the school-level reality.
Poorly designed library databases that frustrate students and staff.
Tokenistic DEI gestures that lack sustained commitment and resources.
Corporate-sponsored programming that advertises to students.
Excessive standardized testing that crowds out creative learning.
Phone-first meetings where people are distracted and not present.
Canned professional development that fails to be practical.
Underfunded after-school programs that rely on unpaid volunteers.
Zero-sum thinking in education policy discussions.
Static collections that don’t reflect community languages and cultures.
Climate denial and attacks on science education.
Single-staff libraries expected to do the work of a full team.
Pretentious book-talk that excludes readers new to literature.
Long commutes when alternate flexible options are possible.
Aggressive fundraising that creates inequities between schools.
Any policy that punishes students for homelessness or food insecurity.
Ignoring student voice in program design.
Stigma around mental health and help-seeking.
Policies that promote globalization.
Over-regulation of businesses.
Government intervention in the economy.
Movements that criticize national traditions or history.
Contemporary art forms perceived as overly abstract or avant-garde.
Efforts to redistribute wealth through government programs or laws.
Chaotic, disorganized systems
Public dissent or protest
Abstract art or unconventional aesthetics
Non-traditional approaches to governance or leadership

beliefs: Public education is a public good and should be adequately funded at local, state, and federal levels.
Libraries are community anchors that must be protected and expanded, not privatized.
Access to books and digital resources is a fundamental right that reduces inequities.
Reading widely cultivates empathy and civic understanding, and should be encouraged across curricula.
Teachers and librarians need time and stable resources, not just mandates.
Trauma-informed practices should be standard in schools serving communities affected by violence, housing instability, and displacement.
Arts and creative expression are essential to youth development and should be funded alongside core academics.
Civic engagement starts young; schools should model democratic deliberation and participatory budgeting where possible.
Libraries should center multilingual collections and staff to reflect student communities.
Digital privacy matters: student data should be protected and not monetized.
Evidence-based policy is important, but qualitative community knowledge should be valued alongside metrics.
Climate change is an urgent crisis; schools should teach climate literacy and reduce institutional carbon footprints.
Immigrant families deserve dignity and protection; schools should be sanctuary spaces that connect families to resources.
Healthcare access, including mental health services, is critical to student success.
Union organizing improves working conditions for staff and outcomes for students.
Restorative justice practices are superior to punitive discipline in building safe school climates.
Libraries and schools should be safe spaces for LGBTQ+ youth with clear anti-bullying policies.
Public transit and walkable neighborhoods improve student attendance and community health.
Small, local initiatives can scale when networks and stable funding are present — so invest in infrastructure.
Reading lists should include books that challenge dominant narratives and highlight marginalized voices.
Civic responsibility includes voting, volunteering, and holding public officials accountable.
Arts partnerships with local nonprofits are valuable but must be equitable, not extractive.
Transparent budgeting in schools builds community trust and allows better advocacy.
Privileging 'college-prep only' mindsets misses varied strengths: trades, apprenticeships, and creative careers deserve respect.
Technology can expand access if deployed with training, maintenance, and privacy protections.
Language preservation (heritage languages) strengthens identity and should be supported in curricula.
Public spaces (libraries, parks) are essential for social cohesion, especially in diverse urban neighborhoods.
Teacher autonomy in curriculum design, within standards, yields more relevant and engaging learning.
Systemic racism and structural inequalities shape student outcomes; addressing them requires policy and practice shifts.
Quality early-childhood literacy interventions pay dividends across a lifespan.
Community-led research and participatory evaluation yield more accurate assessments of program impact.
Small, consistent acts of kindness (mentorship, listening) have outsized effects on adolescent trajectories.
Fiscal austerity often worsens social problems; strategic public investment can be transformative.
Public art and youth-created works should be integrated into civic spaces — they humanize policy.
Libraries should resist corporate branding and maintain independent curation.
Privacy and freedom of expression must be balanced; protecting students from hate speech while protecting access is complex but necessary.
Youth voice must be central in program design — token youth advisory councils are insufficient without power and budget.
National sovereignty should be prioritized over international agreements.
Traditional family structures are the foundation of a stable society.
Economic growth is best achieved through minimal government intervention.
Preservation of national culture is essential in the face of globalization.
Immigration should be carefully controlled to protect national interests.
Policies to redistribute wealth are counterproductive and undermine individual initiative.
If you work hard, you can achieve success and should be able to keep the fruits of your labor.
Authority and order are essential for a functioning society.
Tradition provides a foundation for stability and continuity.
Discipline and structure foster personal and collective success.
Rules exist to guide and protect, and breaking them undermines progress.
Strong leadership is necessary to avoid anarchy and inefficiency.
skills: Library management and operations: circulation workflows, collection development, interlibrary loan basics.
Information literacy instruction: lesson planning for research, source evaluation, citation support.
Cataloging and metadata fundamentals (Dewey familiarity, experience with Evergreen and Koha catalog systems).
Grant writing and small-donor fundraising: ability to draft, budget, and report on $5k–$20k grants.
Program design for youth: after-school curriculum development, assessment, culminating public showcases.
Conflict de-escalation and restorative circles facilitation.
Trauma-informed practice and student-centered pedagogy.
Basic digital tools: Google Workspace, Microsoft Office, Canva, Adobe InDesign for program materials.
Social media management for community engagement (Instagram, Twitter/X) and basic content creation.
Public speaking and workshop facilitation for staff and student audiences.
Community outreach and partnership-building with local arts organizations and NGOs.
Simple web maintenance (editing a WordPress or district site) and HTML/CSS familiarity to troubleshoot pages.
Data collection and simple analysis for program reporting (Google Forms, Excel/Sheets pivots).
Photography and layout for zines and exhibits.
Mentoring and training new staff and volunteers.
Bilingual communication: conversational Korean (heritage language), able to navigate basic Korean-language family conversations and translate community resources with help.
Basic first aid and CPR certified; trauma-response trained.
Time management and event logistics for large student events (300+ attendees).
Collaborative curriculum design with classroom teachers (ELA, history, art).
Advocacy and testimony: experience presenting at school board meetings and bargaining sessions.

general: Carries a battered library tote with a water bottle, planner, a rotating pile of books, stickers, and chapstick.
Begins each morning by scanning overnight emails, then blocks two focused hours for student-facing work before paperwork.
Sends clear, brief follow-up emails after meetings with bulleted action items and deadlines.
Keeps a visible calendar of after-school programming and posts it on the library door and the school website.
Regularly asks students for feedback via sticky-note surveys or quick digital polls.
Frequently benchmarks programming against similar schools in the district and shares findings with colleagues.
Celebrates small wins publicly (student zine launches, grant approvals) to build morale.
Tends to overbook herself with too many committees; periodically enacts a 'no-meeting' day to recalibrate.
Uses analog sticky notes for immediate priorities and transfers them to a digital task manager later.
When overwhelmed, takes a 10–15 minute walk to the nearest park to reset.
Maintains rituals: Friday ‘new books’ shelf refresh and a monthly book club for staff.
Prefers to solve conflicts through listening and mediated conversation rather than punishment.
Often stays after school to supervise club exhibitions and to debrief with student leaders.
Volunteers as a community liaison for newcomer families on enrollment days.
Is conscientious about returning borrowed items on time and expects students to respect due dates with compassionate flexibility.
Frequently attends events celebrating national heritage.
Engages in discussions about political philosophy and economics.
Displays national symbols in personal and professional settings.
Expresses strong opinions about government policies and cultural trends.
Protests against laws that are meant to reduce inequality.
Criticizes people who do not follow rules or protocols.
Organizes belongings and workspace meticulously to reflect control.
Shows visible discomfort in unstructured or informal settings.
Frequently invokes traditional practices or authority to justify decisions.

morning: Wakes around 6:30 AM, drinks water and does a 20-minute yoga/stretch routine.
Prepares coffee (pour-over or small espresso) and a simple breakfast (oatmeal or toast with kimchi on Sundays).
Quickly reviews the day's schedule and highlights three non-negotiable tasks for the day.
Checks public transit alerts and chooses between biking, metro, or driving depending on weather and equipment for the day.
workday: Arrives at school by 8:00 AM. Greets security and cafeteria staff by name.
Teaches two library classes in the morning (one research skills session and one literature circle).
Midday administrative block: responds to emails, processes new materials, updates the catalog, approves purchase orders.
Afternoon: supervises after-school clubs, meets with partnering artists, runs weekly teen zine workshop.
Uses planning periods to prep lesson materials and to meet with teachers about cross-curricular units.
evening: Leaves school around 5:30–6:00 PM on most days; twice a month stays later for community events.
Cooks a simple dinner, often incorporating leftovers and vegetable-forward recipes.
Spends 30–60 minutes reading for pleasure (YA fiction, essays, or a novel) before bed.
Checks slack/messages once more in the evening, sets priorities for the next day, and practices a short mindfulness breathing exercise before sleep.
weekend: Saturday: farmers' market in the morning, community arts events or volunteer tutoring in the afternoon.
Sunday: meal prepping, balcony gardening chores, a longer hike or bike ride when weather permits, and planning the week's library displays and programming.
Once per month participates in a coalition meeting of local librarians to share resources and advocacy strategies.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active. Regular moderate exercise (yoga, hiking, occasional trail runs). Seasonal allergies (pollen) that flare in spring, managed with OTC antihistamines. Dental and vision up to date. No chronic physical diseases diagnosed. Maintains a balanced diet with occasional indulgences.
health.mental: Receives weekly therapy (CBT and reflective practices) for workplace stress and mild generalized anxiety. Has used short-course SSRIs in the past during particularly stressful seasons; currently stabilizing with therapy, sleep hygiene, and peer support. Practices mindfulness and community connection as protective factors.
health.medical_history: No major surgeries. Childhood ear infections but no long-term complications. Up-to-date on vaccinations. Has a history of occasional migraines triggered by inadequate sleep or extended screen time; manages with hydration, rest, and OTC pain relievers when necessary.
health.functional: Able to perform full job duties; occasionally requests schedule adjustments when dealing with high-intensity community crises or family needs. Prioritizes self-care days after long community events.

relationships.name: Hyun Park (mother)
relationships.description: First-generation Korean immigrant, retired nurse, lives in a Seattle suburb. Warm, practical, skilled cook and a supportive listener. Speaks primarily Korean, with some English.

relationships.name: Michael Sullivan (father)
relationships.description: Second-generation Irish-American, high-school teacher (retired), lives in Massachusetts. Encouraged Maya's love of literature early on; they speak by phone weekly and he visits once a year.

relationships.name: Evelyn Park-Sullivan (younger sister, 29)
relationships.description: Works in community health in Portland. Close and confidant; they co-host a monthly virtual book club and trade recipe experiments.

relationships.name: Jordan Reyes (partner)
relationships.description: Non-binary partner, 33, works as a community arts organizer; cohabitates in a two-bedroom apartment. Shares domestic duties, collaborates on program ideas, and co-manages a rescue dog.

relationships.name: Junie (rescue dog)
relationships.description: Four-year-old mixed-breed rescue. Calm in the home, loves kids at school events, and is symbolic of Maya's patient, nurturing side.

relationships.name: School colleagues
relationships.description: A network of teachers (ELA, history, art) who rely on Maya for research modules; a formal mentor (senior librarian) who meets quarterly; and a group of peer librarians across the district for resource-sharing.

relationships.name: Community partners
relationships.description: Leads contacts at a local arts nonprofit, the public library system, and an immigrant-family support NGO — these relationships supply visiting artists, bilingual volunteers, and family outreach resources.

relationships.name: Union contacts
relationships.description: Active member in the local educators' union with a few close colleagues who coordinate on staffing and library funding negotiations.

other_facts: Grew up in a bilingual household (Korean and English) in a mid-sized city; early childhood was split between grandparents' home and a lively, book-filled household.
Has felt the dual identity of being Korean and Irish-descended; navigates both cultures and celebrates both sets of holidays.
First teaching experience was as a high-school volunteer tutor during college, which cemented her interest in youth literacy.
Spent a semester abroad in Dublin during undergrad, which deepened her appreciation for public libraries and community archives.
Her undergraduate honors thesis explored diaspora narratives in contemporary poetry.
Chose an MLIS because she values public access to information and wanted a practical pathway to community impact.
Once organized a pop-up 'library salon' in a community center that brought 200+ neighborhood residents for storytelling and resource sign-ups.
Has been arrested once at a nonviolent protest for civil disobedience defending public library funding; it was a single citation later dismissed — the event strengthened her advocacy network.
Received a district-level 'Innovative Educator' microgrant for a digital storytelling project that paired teens with local elders for oral histories.
Maintains a small personal zine collection with hand-collated issues written by teens from her programs.
Is allergic to cats (mild) which is why the household is dog-centric.
Owns a battered first-edition children's book that belonged to her grandmother; it is kept in a special box and read aloud at family gatherings.
Loves the smell of new books and finds shelving new arrivals a calming ritual.
Has a scar on her left knuckle from a woodworking project that went slightly wrong; it’s a badge of the maker life.
Volunteered in a summer literacy camp in Guatemala serving immigrant communities, which informed her approach to culturally responsive pedagogy.
Collects old library cards and stamps from decommissioned branches — a small hobby that connects past systems with present practice.
Has a single small tattoo of an open book on the inside of her wrist as a discreet personal symbol of vocation.
Learnt to ride a bike late as an adult and now prefers biking short distances to errands when weather allows.
Did a year of substitute teaching between grad school and securing her current role, which helped her understand classroom rhythms.
Maintains a modest emergency fund but carries student loan debt from graduate school (~$30k remaining), prioritizing steady payments while saving for home down payment.
Has moderate experience testifying at city council and school board meetings; comfortable in public advocacy roles.
Keeps a shelf of books about pedagogy, community organizing, and craft-making next to novels for personal reading.
Has negotiated with multiple vendors to secure discounted technology for students (refurbished laptops, donated hotspots).
Once coordinated a partnership that brought a visiting graphic novelist to co-develop a curriculum unit; the project produced a student anthologized comic.
Enjoys quiet, ritualized celebrations on birthdays: a homemade cake, a small gathering of close friends, and a tradition of selecting a new book as a present.
Is a decent amateur cook; signature dishes include a kimchi-forward stir-fry and a hearty Irish stew adapted with seasonal Pacific Northwest vegetables.
Has a photo wall in her home with Polaroids of student exhibitions, community events, and family moments.
Prefers to buy secondhand furniture and refinish pieces, which balances budget and aesthetic values.
Has a small side-income from occasional speaking engagements and workshops for other district librarians and educators.
Values transparency and creates post-mortem notes after every large program to archive lessons learned for future organizers.
Has a ritual of writing a gratitude list each Sunday night, which helps maintain perspective during busy school cycles.
Speaks at least one short speech in Korean at community cultural events, which is always met with warm appreciation.
Once had a student-run pop-up library in an underused school hallway that grew into a sustained peer-led lending library.
Went through a period of burnout three years ago which led to restructuring workload, setting firmer boundaries, and beginning therapy.
Is slowly learning to say 'no' and to delegate, though she still sometimes reclaims tasks she could let go.
Keeps a running document of program ideas and future grant concepts that she adds to whenever inspiration strikes.
Her favorite childhood comfort book was a well-worn copy of Where the Wild Things Are; she reads it at family gatherings and notes how stories endure across generations.
Has a quirky habit of naming seasonal reading shelves (e.g., 'Rainy Day Retreat', 'Small Joys') to encourage browsing.
Once got into a heated but productive debate on a panel about censorship vs. age-appropriate access — the experience sharpened her public advocacy skills.
Is known among colleagues as the person who makes the best program flyers — part design sense, part empathy for audience language.
Dreams of one day opening a small community press with a focus on youth voices and immigrant narratives but is pragmatic about the steps needed to get there.
Keeps an emergency bag in the car with a blanket, spare phone charger, snacks, a small first-aid kit, and copies of essential paperwork for community outreach days.
Has a soft spot for the neighborhood baker who provides discounted pastries for after-school programs in exchange for student art on display.
Believes deeply in slow relationship-building with families and spends time attending PTA cultural nights to build trust.
Has a standing informal mentorship with a retired archivist who advises on community-collection preservation and oral-history archiving.
Is energized by late-spring grant cycles when potential funding could expand stable staffing and programming for the next school year.
You were influenced by your upbringing in a community that emphasized traditional values and self-reliance.
Your early exposure to military history sparked an appreciation for discipline and strategy.
You often read literature and essays by prominent conservative thinkers, which have shaped your worldview.
Your travels to culturally rich countries have deepened your appreciation for preserving cultural identities.
Has a deep respect for historical figures known for their leadership and decisiveness.
Collects memorabilia or objects related to hierarchy and authority (e.g., medals, antique military paraphernalia).
Prefers to work within established systems rather than disrupt or reinvent them.
Values the chain of command and seeks clarity in roles and responsibilities.
